Dear Father,
As I am writing I will write a few lines to one that is so near and dear to me as you. I am enjoying life as it passes pretty well we are all well.  Emery says if he had his land disposed of and his cattle he would go to California in the spring.  I think he would be very foolish don't you as he has a good farm I think he had better stay and work it for all of spending what little he has got dont you Father.  I would like to have you see to my things that I left a home I dont want to have them destroyed for I may need them some day.  I intend to teach school next season if nothing happens. Herman thinks that I am better qualified than most of the teachers.  I might of taken a school this winter but thought it would be most to much to board around in cold weather. Mary has got a first rate fellow for a man sister he is very good to me I like him much

She brought us some potatoes that they raised on the farm she said she knew we had to buy all of ours, and thought they would (*come??) good.

Oshkosh. Sept. 11th "87
Dear Mother, 
Why don't you write. I haven't heard a word from you for over a month. This is the second or third letter I have written. 
I hope you are not sick. As soon as you get this, write and let me know the cause of your silence. 
I am well, and fat as a pig. - I was never so fat as I have been this Summer. There is an Indian Dr. in town. and he is a wonder in the medical profession. 
I would like to go to him and have him treat my lungs; but have not got the money.
We have been to hear him for

about a week past, - he gave a concert and lecture in the old Rink building on Algoma St., you remember where that was, dont you? Tom is in my lap, - as happy as a bug. - He says he loves me. I had a letter from Mr. Schroeder the other day. - he says my land is all right. - that it was not cancelled. 
I think that Mayberry wanted to scare me knot selling it. Dont you? Well! I didn't scare worth a cent. 
You bet I was glad when I received the letter saying it was all right. I'm all alone in the house today. - Mrs. Smith has gone across the river, & Dan is working.

Mrs. Oakes was down and made me a visit. - We had a splendid time but she didn't stay long enough. 
I had a letter from Nora Gagr? White yesterday. - she is getting along fine. They have a little girl she just begins to run around.

I wont write any more; for perhaps you wont get this, but if you do. - write as soon as rec'd. - Now be sure. 
With Love, I will close. - 
Your affectinate Daughter.
